questions.text: Where in your neck does it hurt the most?

options.label: Front of my neck / throat area
Where my neck meets the base of my skull
Where my neck meets my shoulder

questions.text: When did the neck pain start?
Did anything happen that might have caused the pain?

options.label: I fell or hit my head
I think I slept in a bad position
Nothing that I know of – it just started

questions.text: How bad is the pain right now? (0 = no pain, 10 = worst ever)
Does the pain travel into your shoulders, arms, or hands?

options.label: No, it stays in my neck
Yes, all the way to my hand or fingers

questions.text: Do you have any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your arms or hands?

options.label: Yes, weakness – I'm dropping things or can't grip well

questions.text: Do you have a headache along with the neck pain?

options.label: Yes, a severe headache – the worst I've ever had

questions.text: Can you turn your head from side to side?

options.label: Somewhat, but it's painful or limited
No, I can barely move my neck

questions.text: Do you have a fever or feel feverish?

red_flag_combinations.message: Neck pain with arm weakness after a trauma could mean a spinal cord injury. Keep your neck still and get emergency help immediately.
Severe headache with neck pain and fever could be a sign of meningitis. This needs emergency evaluation right away.
Severe headache with an inability to move your neck (neck stiffness) needs emergency evaluation to rule out meningitis or bleeding.
Arm weakness with pain radiating into both arms may indicate significant spinal cord compression. This needs urgent evaluation.
Severe neck pain with fever could be a spinal infection or abscess. This needs urgent medical attention.
Severe neck pain after trauma needs imaging to rule out a fracture. Do not move your neck unnecessarily and seek emergency care.
